timeline.message: Ensure that param converters for RR aren't under the 'java' package

Prevent multiple HTTP annotations on RESTEasy Reactive endpoints

The spec doesn't mandate this behavior, but it can lead to unexpected results,
so let's not allow it

timeline.bodyText:
This method signature is a mine field:

Type paramType
ParameterType type
String elementType
String signature

And of course, we reverse the order of type…signature to signature, type in the call below :(
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Indeed... I'll move the signature String to at least make it less likely to fail
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: Pretty scary that the TCK doesn't test this.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: BTW, do we need a test for generic input types, or is this part of the next commits with List<String> request bodies?
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: You mean something like List<T> for the input? If so, then we don't have such a test and we should add it.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Well, any generic type, really.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Test added in the last commit
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: This is confusing given that String is not generic, so if type == String.class  then genericType == String.class must also be true or else something is super wrong in RR.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText:
The idea here is to differentiate between String and List<String>. In the latter case, genericType will be a ParameterizedTypeImpl which we assume Jackson can handle.
A simple String, we know Jackson can't handle.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: But if genericType is List<String> then type == List.class, not String.class.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Yeah, which is why the method returns false, no?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: My point is that if String.class.equals(type) then the second part of the condition must ALWAYS be true. So it's redundant.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: OK, I see your point
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
Checked this again and now I see why I did what I did.
When genericType is List<String>, then type is String. This feels very wrong, but I am not sure I want to tackle it... (see my other comment).
I'll make a lame attempt to fix it, but if things start to break, I really prefer to leave it as is for now and fix later properly on when we are all refreshed :)
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Ah, so that's another consequence of the other issue. I can try to find the underlying issue tomorrow, I'd prefer to at least know what it is before adding weird stuff like this.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Yeah. I'll look into it more
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I'll let you know what I find, but indeed the last commit might have to be changed considerably.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
I see where I messed up - looking to see what can be done.
Thanks for insisting :)
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
Fixed, properly.
Thanks again for being vigilant
replies.author: geoand

timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Well, I copied this from some of JAX-RS specific snippet in the Jackson codebase. I thought it was odd, but said 🤷🏼 :)
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: It is odd. https://stackoverflow.com/a/477819/56994 says application/javascript is for JSONP. This doesn't even check the main type. It feels wrong.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: OK, I'll remove it
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: I don't see why we do this, given that we refuse to unserialise a String parameter in the JSON reader. Object above should just work and match List<String> via inheritance.
timeline.author: FroMage
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -47,6 +47,9 @@ void additionalProviders(BuildProducer<AdditionalBeanBuildItem> additionalBean,
         additionalReaders
                 .produce(new MessageBodyReaderBuildItem(JacksonMessageBodyReader.class.getName(), Object.class.getName(),
                         Collections.singletonList(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)));
+        additionalReaders
+                .produce(new MessageBodyReaderBuildItem(JacksonMessageBodyReader.class.getName(), String.class.getName(),

replies.bodyText: This is needed, otherwise the order with which the reader is determined turns out to be wrong.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
OK, but why? Especially for a List<String> I don't think we should ever match with a String type, not for JSON.
It could make sense for the parameter convertors we support but those don't use readers.
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText:
When I was looking I saw it was because we were looking up readers for String,  not List.
Now I am pretty sure that is a problem in itself, but I would prefer to keep this fix for now (as it can affect a lot of users) and deal with it more holistically if the need arises (i.e. we encounter more problems with reader selection).
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure, I think looking up readers for String when we have List<String> is wrong and could lead to all sorts of troubles. We should find out why that is and not add weird workarounds that we'll surely forget to remove and then wonder why they are here ;)
replies.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText:
I've been burned by the readers too many times to have the will to fix it properly a few days before PTO :).
If we add the workaround, we will at least unblock a very common problem the code has now and thus allow us to see if there are any further problem. If there are, then I wholeheartedly agree to take a more extensive look at it.
replies.author: geoand

timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Nope :)
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: Sounds like this could be abstracted somewhere common. Especially given that it has no json dependency, we could put this in -common
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Will do
replies.author: geoand

timeline.message: Add generic handling test for MessageBodyReader
Add generic handling test for MessageBodyReader

Don't run ContainerRequestFilters on subresources

This behavior is similar to how RESTEasy behaves
Ensure that param converters for RR aren't under the 'java' package
Prevent NPE and IOOBE when getting matched resources

Prevent multiple HTTP annotations on RESTEasy Reactive endpoints

The spec doesn't mandate this behavior, but it can lead to unexpected results,
so let's not allow it
Also handle @JsonView on slow path in RESTEasy Reactive
Properly pass the generic type to message body readers

Don't use converters for the body of a Request

The spec is explicit that converters are for types other
than body (which are handled by the proper MessageBodyReader).

Don't run ContainerRequestFilters on subresources

This behavior is similar to how RESTEasy behaves

timeline.bodyText: Why is this required? Don't we match Collection and Map with Object? Why do we need this for them and not List?
timeline.author: FroMage
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -47,6 +48,12 @@ void additionalProviders(BuildProducer<AdditionalBeanBuildItem> additionalBean,
         additionalReaders
                 .produce(new MessageBodyReaderBuildItem(JacksonMessageBodyReader.class.getName(), Object.class.getName(),
                         Collections.singletonList(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)));
+        additionalReaders
+                .produce(new MessageBodyReaderBuildItem(JacksonMessageBodyReader.class.getName(), Collection.class.getName(),

replies.bodyText:
We need Collection, because when checking interfaces, Object (as a "super-class") doesn't get checked (I am pretty sure that it's spec mandated).
By adding Collection, all collections will work just fine.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: The spec mandates that we don't check Object for interface types? That'd be insane. I can't believe that.
replies.author: FroMage
FroMage

replies.bodyText: I do think the interface thing was a special in the spec, but I need to check.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: So it seems like the spec doesn't mention anything. Moreoever, we do that same trick you mentioned for writers, so I updated the PR to use it for readers as well
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: We should check the application main type, because this may match image/* ATM due to ignoring the main type and allowing subtype wildcards.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Good idea
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: In theory, @RestPath is not required here
timeline.author: FroMage

timeline.bodyText: Here, though, I do wonder if @RestPath is required. I suppose yes, because there's no @Path matching. I am not sure what the spec says about sub-resources allowing @Path matching. Is it allowed/supported?
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: Yeah, here it is required because there is no other way to know
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText: Is there a reason to overwrite the pathParamValue for locators? Is it because they can declare new path parameters? Otherwise we can just keep the original pathParamValue and no need to add a field to save them.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText: The subresource can indeed declare different parameters - they don't need to be same as the original. So to support that case we do indeed need to override
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: OK
replies.author: FroMage

timeline.bodyText: Can a locator method return a sub-resource which returns a locator method? As in, can we have two levels of locators? If yes, then we need more than an extra field, we need a stack of them.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText:
That's a very good question, but the spec doesn't seem to say anything about that nor do I see any test in the TCK.
I would say let's not complicate it unless we actually see something like that in the wild
replies.author: geoand

timeline.bodyText:
This appears to imply that you can only access path params in a sub-resource by matching against the locator method, so the sub-resource can't have path params of its own, right?
So, is it true? The spec is confusing about this. If it is true, why do we not keep the original path param values then, instead of adding a new field to save the original ones?
Also, why can't we use context.getLocatorTarget().getPathParameterIndexes()? I'm sure there's a good reason, but I don't get it.
timeline.author: FroMage

replies.bodyText:
By reading the spec, I can't really tell what the intended behavior is.
I'll try and see if we can keep the paths of the original request and see how the tests behave
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
I tried keeping the original values and some of the tests fail.
The approach in this PR however passes all old and new tests
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Then perfect :)
replies.author: FroMage

timeline.message: Make sure that List<String> can be read as JSON input
Handle path params in subresource methods
Also check for Object when a reader of an interface is needed
Add generic handling test for MessageBodyReader

Don't run ContainerRequestFilters on subresources

This behavior is similar to how RESTEasy behaves
Handle path params in subresource methods
Handle path params in subresource methods
